entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 2:00PM EDT until April 3 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of northern New Jersey, including the following counties, Hunterdon and Somerset.
* WHEN...Until 800 PM EDT Wednesday.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 159 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain. Flooding is already occurring in the warned area including along the Neshanic at Reaville. Between 0.5 and 1 inch of rain has fallen. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 1.5 inches are possible in the warned area. - For South Branch Raritan River at Stanton: At 1:30pm the stage was 6.11 feet. Flood Stage is 8 feet. ... For Neshanic at Reaville: At 1:45pm the stage was 6.82 feet. Flood Stage is 6.5 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 2:00PM EDT until April 4 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Pennsylvania...
Juniata River at Huntingdon affecting Huntingdon County.
For the Juniata River...including Huntingdon...Moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Juniata River at Huntingdon.
* WHEN...Until tomorrow evening.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, High water will begin to affect the Ames Plaza on the right, or south bank. At 13.0 feet, Several homes located outside of the levee system will flood. At 14.5 feet, Approximate level of the FEMA 10% Annual Chance Flood level (10-year flood). At 15.0 feet, A number of homes outside the protective works and along Standing Stone Creek will flood. Backwater on Standing Stone Creek also affects the athletic field.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:32 PM EDT Wednesday the stage was 12.9 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 1:32 PM EDT Wednesday was 12.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 14.0 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage early tomorrow afternoon. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 1:58PM EDT until April 4 at 12:24AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Mount Holly NJ has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Pennsylvania...
East Branch Brandywine Creek Below Downingtown affecting Chester County.
For the Brandywine Creek...including Downingtown...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...East Branch Brandywine Creek below Downingtown.
* WHEN...From this afternoon to just after midnight tonight.
* IMPACTS...At 6.0 feet, Open adjacent land next to the creek floods. At 8.0 feet, Dowlin Forge Road begins to flood. At 9.0 feet, High water on the Brandywine sends backwater up Beaver Creek. Beaver Creek floods inundating parks and the Downingtown Little League fields.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1:45 PM EDT Wednesday the stage was 7.3 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 1:45 PM EDT Wednesday was 7.3 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 8.1 feet late this afternoon. With more rain on the way, additional rises are possible. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 7.9 feet on 08/19/2021. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

Locations impacted include... Palm Coast, Ocala, Palatka, Flagler Beach, Bunnell, Crescent City, Interlachen, Pomona Park, Hastings, and East Palatka.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 3 at 1:56PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary: Isolated strong easterly wind gusts near 40 to 50 mph have developed this afternoon, as strong low pressure begins to approach from the south. The higher gusts are mainly restricted to higher exposed terrain above 400 ft elevation. These wind gusts may result in some isolated instances of tree damage or power outages, due in part to the combination of heavier rainfall putting extra stress on trees. Use caution and take shelter indoors if sudden strong wind gusts develop in your area. Winds will ease heading into this evening as the low pressure center approaches, from south to north.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Sussex; Warren; Morris; Hunterdon; Somerset; Mercer; Carbon; Monroe; Berks; Lehigh; Northampton; Delaware; Philadelphia; Western Chester; Eastern Chester; Western Montgomery; Eastern Montgomery; Upper Bucks; Lower Bucks

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 3 at 1:50PM EDT until April 3 at 4:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is possible.
* WHERE...Portions of north central Maryland, including the following area, Washington, northwest Virginia, including the following areas, Clarke, Frederick VA, Northern Virginia Blue Ridge, Page, Shenandoah and Warren, and West Virginia, including the following areas, Berkeley, Hampshire, Hardy, Jefferson and Morgan.
* WHEN...Until 4 PM EDT this afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Multiple rounds of showers and thunderstorms are expected through this afternoon. Additional rain amounts of 1 to 2 inches of rain are most likely, with localized amounts up to 3 inches possible. This may result in flooding of small streams and creeks. Flash flooding is possible. - Please visit www.weather.gov/safety/flood for flood safety and preparedness information

entry.summary:

entry.summary:

* WHERE...Sierra Nevada from Yosemite National Park to northern portions of Kern County.
* WHEN...Valid from 11 PM PDT Wednesday evening until 11 PM PDT Friday evening.
* IMPACTS...Travel will be very difficult. Strong winds could cause tree damage.

* WHERE...A portion of southeast Ohio, including the following county, Washington.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 3 at 12:15PM EDT by NWS Louisville KY
entry.summary:
Gusty winds from the west are expected today, especially this afternoon and evening when wind gusts of 30 to 40 mph are expected. Showers and perhaps a few thunderstorms this afternoon and evening could also produce localized gusts in excess of 40 mph and small hailstones.
These strong westerly winds could make travel a bit more challenging for high-profile vehicles on north-south oriented highways.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 12:13PM EDT until April 5 at 2:30AM EDT by NWS State College PA
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in State College PA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Pennsylvania...
Juniata River at Lewistown affecting Juniata and Mifflin Counties.
For the Juniata River...including Lewistown...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Juniata River at Lewistown.
* WHEN...From this afternoon to early Friday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 23.0 feet, Basements of a few homes in the lowest lying areas will flood. Backwater on Kishacoquillas Creek will affect the athletic fields. At 24.5 feet, FEMA 10% Annual Chance Flood Level (10-year flood). At 25.0 feet, Basement flooding occurs in the low lying areas adjacent to the river and Kishacoquillas creek. Athletic fields will be inundated. At 27.0 feet, Several homes on West Elizabeth Street will flood. Route 22 is also affected. At 28.0 feet, Considerable flood damage occurs to homes and businesses in and around lewistown.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:30 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 21.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late this afternoon to a crest of 26.0 feet tomorrow morning. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 23.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

At 19.5 feet, The Monongahela Parking Wharf is completely flooded. At 20.0 feet, Water is up to one foot deep in the lower areas of the North Shore Riverwalk. At 22.0 feet, The Tenth Street Bypass floods. At 22.5 feet, The fountain plaza is flooded. At 24.0 feet, Water enters the outer pool of the fountain. At 24.9 feet, Water entes the inner pool of the fountain. At 25.0 feet, The Parkway Central (also known as the bathtub) is closed by flooding. Lower North Side businesses are affected. At 26.0 feet, State Correctional Institution Pittsburgh is impacted. At 27.6 feet, The fountain in Point State Park is completely submerged. At 28.0 feet, Pumping operations begin on Neville Island. The Wood Street T station facilities are impacted. Fort Pitt Boulevard is closed. At 29.0 feet, River Avenue on the North Side begins to flood.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:45 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 24.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 18.0 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise above flood stage late this afternoon to 27.0 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow afternoon to 18.5 feet Friday evening. It will rise to 19.0 feet Saturday morning. It will then fall to 18.3 feet Saturday evening. It will rise to 18.7 feet early Sunday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 25.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 27.1 feet on 09/11/2018. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 12:07PM EDT until April 3 at 5:00PM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues.
* WHERE...Portions of western Maryland, including the following counties, Allegany and Garrett and eastern West Virginia, including the following counties, Grant and Mineral.
* WHEN...Until 500 PM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring. Low-water crossings are inundated with water and may not be passable.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 1207 PM EDT, Doppler radar and automated rain gauges indicated heavy rain had fallen across the warned area. Between 1.5 and 3 inches of rain have fallen. Several road closures have been reported, and several streams are reaching minor flood stage. - Additional rainfall amounts up to 0.5 inches are possible in the warned area. - Some locations that will experience flooding include... Cumberland... Frostburg... Keyser... Mountain Lake Park... Oakland... Westernport... Bel Air... Paw Paw... Bayard... Bittinger... La Vale... Fort Ashby... Lonaconing... Piedmont... Grantsville... Loch Lynn Heights... Friendsville... Deer Park... Accident... Elk Garden... - Please visit weather.gov/safety/flood for flood safety and preparedness information

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 12:06PM EDT until April 5 at 9:30AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Indiana...Illinois...
Wabash River.
Wildcat Creek near Lafayette.
.Repeated rounds of showers and thunderstorms Monday and Tuesday brought 1 to 4 inches of rainfall to most parts of central and southern Indiana. This is bringing rises to area waterways. Minor flooding is expected at most locations in the Wabash basin. Persons with interests along area rivers should monitor forecasts for updates.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wildcat Creek near Lafayette.
* WHEN...Until late Friday morning.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 12:01PM EDT until April 5 at 12:36PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Ohio...
Wills Creek At Cambridge affecting Guernsey County.
Muskingum River At Coshocton affecting Coshocton County.
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Ohio...
Stillwater Creek At Uhrichsville affecting Tuscarawas County.
.Widespread moderate to heavy rainfall has occurred across the region over the past 48 hours. Rainfall of up to 4.00 inches is resulting in rapid rises on rivers. Over the next 24 hours, rivers are forecast to crest above flood stage.
* WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wills Creek at Cambridge.
* WHEN...Until early Friday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Overflowing of poor drainage and low lying areas will result in minor flooding along wills creek. At 16.0 feet, Basement flooding begins through floor drains and other sewer connections. Local interruptions in sanitary service may occur along Gordon's Run from 3rd Street to 6th Street. At 17.0 feet, Water overflows wills Creek Valley Road to a depth of 2 feet. Water reaches a depth of 1 foot on North Eighth Street. At 18.0 feet, Flood waters begin effecting apartments along Wills Creek Valley Road. Southgate Parkway will also begin flooding near Woodlawn Avenue. At 20.0 feet, Flood waters reach residential areas on the west side of Cambridge. At 22.0 feet, The North 8th Street Bridge near the school campus is impassable. Flood waters reach Wills Creek Valley Drive near the County Road 35 Bridge. The north side of Cambridge is close to being cut off from access. Water from Wills Creek will flood the west end of Cambridge. At 23.0 feet, Flood waters are expected to reach the Cambridge Square Plaza on Route 209. South 10th Street and Orchard Avenue should also begin to feel the effects of the rising waters. Seek higher ground and do not attempt to cross flooded roadways.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:15 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 20.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:15 AM EDT Wednesday was 20.3 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 21.0 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage Friday morning to 11.5 feet early Saturday morning. It will rise to 12.2 feet early Saturday afternoon. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 19.3 feet on 01/13/2005. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

For the Ocmulgee River Basin...including Jackson, Juliette, Griffin, Juliette, Dames Ferry, Macon, Macon, Hawkinsville, Hawkinsville, Clinchfield, Byron, Abbeville, McRae, Scotland, Lumber City...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ocmulgee River near Macon.
* WHEN...From late Thursday night to Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 19.0 feet, Minor flooding continues. The Macon Greenway Ocmulgee Heritage Trail will begin to flood in areas just north of the Martin Luther King Boulevard bridge. The public should not use this portion of the trail. In addition...the lowest sections of the Charles Jones Gateway Park will flood. Portions of agricultural lands well downstream will be under two feet of water.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:30 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 9.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early Friday morning to a crest of 19.4 feet early Friday afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 18.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 19.5 feet on 02/16/1997. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 11:56AM EDT until April 4 at 9:30AM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Pennsylvania...
Conemaugh River At Seward affecting Westmoreland and Indiana Counties.
Youghiogheny River At Connellsville affecting Fayette County.
.Widespread moderate to heavy rain has fallen across the region over the past 48 hours. Rainfall amounts of up to 4.00 inches are resulting in rapid rises. The following rivers are forecast to reach or exceed floodstage over the next 24 hours.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Youghiogheny River at Connellsville.
* WHEN...Until late tomorrow morning.
* IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Flooding begins in the vicinity of Yough Park. At 14.0 feet, Several inches of water floods basements of about 30 homes along left bank. River is bankfull along the left bank just downstream from the Crawford Street Bridge. Water reaches the level of the Hurricane Ivan flood of September 18, 2004. At 14.1 feet, Water reaches level of March 3, 2015. At 16.0 feet, About 100 homes on the west side of Connellsville flood in the areas of Fifth, Sixth and Seventh Streets.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:15 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 14.3 feet. - Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:15 AM EDT Wednesday was 14.3 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 14.7 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage late tonight to 7.3 feet Friday morning. It will rise to 7.8 feet early Saturday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 14.6 feet on 11/27/1985. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 11:56AM EDT until April 4 at 12:00PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...Forecast flooding changed from Moderate to Major severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Pennsylvania...
Youghiogheny River At Sutersville affecting Westmoreland and Allegheny Counties.
.Widespread moderate to heavy rains have fallen across the region over the past 48 hours. Rainfall amounts of up to 4.00 inches over this period is resulting in rapid rises over much of the region. Over the next 24 hours, these locations are forecast to reach or exceed flood stage.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Youghiogheny River at Sutersville.
* WHEN...Until early tomorrow afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 20.0 feet, Residential basement flooding in Sutersville begins in homes along the right bank. Flooding also begins in the West Newton business district 5 miles upstream. At 20.7 feet, Flood reaches the level reached on March 5, 2015. At 20.7 feet, Water reaches the level reached during Hurricane Ivan September 18, 2004. At 23.0 feet, floodwaters reach the railroad tracks on the left bank. At 26.0 feet, Water reaches 1st Avenue on the north side of town. Basements are flooded in homes along all of 1st Avenue. About 25 homes are affected.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:15 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 21.7 feet. - Bankfull stage is 0.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:15 AM EDT Wednesday was 21.7 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 24.0 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage tomorrow morning to 9.9 feet early Friday afternoon. It will rise to 10.4 feet Saturday morning. It will then fall again and remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 20.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 24.7 feet on 09/14/1971. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

CR 500N west of CR 250W is flooded blocking vehicular access to residences near the river bank. Lowell Public Access site is open but ramp is totally flooded. Water close to one residence at Shelby CR 1000S and CR 900W.

It will then fall below flood stage early Friday afternoon. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 11:45AM EDT until April 7 at 8:45AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Indiana...
East Fork White River at Seymour and Columbus.
Driftwood River near Edinburgh.
Big Blue River at Shelbyville.
Flatrock River near Columbus.
.Repeated rounds of showers and thunderstorms Monday and Tuesday brought 1 to 4 inches of rainfall to most parts of central and southern Indiana. This is bringing rises to area waterways. Minor flooding is expected at many locations in the East Fork White basin, with the Eel River at Bowling Green approaching moderate flooding. Persons with interests along area rivers should closely monitor forecasts for updates.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...East Fork White River at Seymour.
* WHEN...Until Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 15.6 feet, Jackson County Sheriff reported following roads closed when the river experienced a minor rise after the Great June 2008 flood: SR 235 east of Medora to Covered Bridge, CR 300N east of Honeytown to Shieldstown, CR 225W between CR 300N and Slab Road River Bridge, CR 410W from US 50 to Vallonia, Newford Road, west from Vehslage Road to the 5000 block east, CR 400E from Newford Road south to Shieldstown, CR 150 E from CR 3000N to CR 4000N, CR 100E from CR 3000N to CR 4000N and CR 700E by CR 800N.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:45 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 11.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage this afternoon to a crest of 15.8 feet tomorrow evening. It will then fall below flood stage Saturday evening. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Jackson, IN; Lawrence, IN; Washington, IN

entry.title: Beach Hazards Statement issued April 3 at 11:21AM EDT until April 3 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Newport/Morehead City NC
entry.summary:

* WHERE...The beaches from Cape Hatteras to Surf City.
* WHEN...Through this evening.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water. Dangerous shore break can throw a swimmer or surfer head first into the bottom causing neck and back injuries. Strong longshore currents will create dangerous swimming conditions.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 3 at 10:21AM CDT by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary: Due to a tight pressure gradient, expect strong gusty west- northwest winds today with gusts up to around 40 mph possible. Showers and isolated afternoon thunderstorms may mix down higher gusts at times. Small hail is possible today, even with non- thunderstorm showers. A cold air funnel or two may also occur. Secure any loose objects and be cautious when driving high profile and lightweight vehicles.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 11:19AM EDT until April 11 at 4:34AM EDT by NWS Indianapolis IN
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana...
White River.
Eel River at Bowling Green.
.Repeated rounds of showers and thunderstorms Monday and Tuesday brought 1 to 4 inches of rainfall to most parts of central and southern Indiana. This is bringing rises to area waterways. Minor flooding is expected at most locations in the White basin, with the Eel River at Bowling Green approaching moderate flooding. Persons with interests along area rivers should closely monitor forecasts for updates.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...White River at Petersburg.
* WHEN...From late tonight to Thursday, April 11.
* IMPACTS...At 20.5 feet, County Road 250 West from State Road 56 floods and blocks the vehicle access to Dodge City. During the March 2008 flood the river remained above this level from late afternoon March 19 through April 9. As mid-March 2011 high water was receding...SR 257 south of Washington reopened when Shoals was at 10.5 feet and falling steadily for the past 2 days.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM EDT Wednesday /9:30 AM CDT Wednesday/ the stage was 8.8 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage just after midnight tonight to a crest of 20.1 feet Sunday morning. It will then fall below flood stage Wednesday, April 10. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Daviess, IN; Gibson, IN; Knox, IN; Pike, IN

entry.title: Winter Weather Advisory issued April 3 at 11:13AM EDT until April 5 at 12:00AM EDT by NWS Baltimore MD/Washington DC
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Snow expected. Total accumulations ranging from 4 to 6 inches above 3,500 feet, 2 to 4 inches between 2,500 and 3,500 feet, and a coating to an inch or two below 2,500 feet. Additional snow accumulation is expected overnight Thursday through Friday.
* WHERE...In Maryland, Garrett County. In Virginia, Western Highland County. In West Virginia, Western Grant and Western Pendleton Counties.
* WHEN...From 8 AM Thursday to midnight EDT Thursday night.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact morning and evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Be prepared for rapidly changing conditions with bursts of heavier snow showers and snow squalls. Visibility will rapidly drop below one-quarter mile at times with roads changing from wet to snow covered at times. The most impacts will be above 2,500 feet in elevation. Interstate 68 will be impacted by this.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 3 at 10:29AM EDT until April 4 at 2:00PM EDT by NWS Buffalo NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of western New York, including the following counties, Allegany, Cattaraugus, Chautauqua, Genesee, Livingston, Monroe, Niagara, Northern Erie, Orleans, Southern Erie and Wyoming.
* WHEN...Through Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - So far between an inch and inch and a half of rain has fallen in the Allegheny River and Upper Genesee River basins, which is causing rises on these rivers. An additional inch of rain is possible during the day today, which may cause minor flooding depending on how much rain falls.
A quarter to half inch of rain fell in the Buffalo Creeks area last night and around a half inch in the Rochester area. An additional inch of rain is possible during today. Depending how much rain falls, this will cause rises on these creeks, with a small risk of generally minor flooding as these creeks respond to the rainfall tonight into Thursday. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Rip Current Statement issued April 3 at 10:11AM AST until April 4 at 6:00AM AST by NWS San Juan PR
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Life-threatening rip current conditions due to breaking waves up to 6 to 7 feet.
* WHERE...Beaches along the northwestern coastline of Puerto Rico from Aguadilla to Arecibo.
* WHEN...Through late tonight.
* IMPACTS...Rip currents that can sweep even the best swimmers away from shore into deeper water where it becomes difficult to return to safety. High waves that can wash over jetties and sweep people and pets onto jagged rocks.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Rip currents can occur anywhere you have breaking waves, like sandy beaches on the open ocean, but can also occur where there are solid structures,like jetties and piers or even rocks jutting out into the ocean.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 8:59AM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Suwannee, Gilchrist and Columbia Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Thursday morning at 900 AM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:00 AM EDT Wednesday the stage was 17.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 17.8 feet Sunday evening. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 3 at 3:04AM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* A strong cold front will move through the Sierra and western NV tonight and Thursday, bringing gusty winds, much colder temperatures, and chances for snow showers.
* Gusty southwest winds will develop this afternoon north of Highway 50 and shift to the Eastern Sierra of Mono and Mineral counties overnight into Thursday morning. This will impact outdoor activities, produce bumpy airplane rides, and cause gusty cross winds for high-profile vehicles, especially along Highway 395, Highway 95, and I-580. Wind gusts along the Sierra crest will exceed 80 mph.
* Snow showers will increase in northeast CA and the Sierra today and spread across the region tonight through Friday. Roads will be slick in the Sierra, especially at night. The higher April sun angle will limit accumulations during the daytime hours. Prepare for possible delays if your plans include travel across the Sierra. Total snow accumulations: Above 7000 feet in Greater Lake Tahoe: greater than 6 inches on the west side of Lake Tahoe and 1 to 2 inches in the Carson Range. Above 7000 feet in Mono County: 3 to 8 inches. Below 7000 feet in Mono County: a trace up to 4 inches. Lowest Nevada valleys: light snow showers, but little or no accumulation.
* Unusually cold air will settle into the area for early April with daytime temperatures 15-20 degrees below normal Thursday and Friday and only warming slightly over the weekend. Hard freezes are almost a certainty each night, even for lower western NV valleys beginning Thursday night. Be ready to protect sensitive plants and wrap exposed irrigation systems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Surprise Valley California; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area; Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake; Northern Washoe County

cap:parameter.value: PERIOD OF COLD AND UNSETTLED WEATHER THROUGH THE WEEKEND

entry.summary:

Use Caution if traveling this afternoon into tonight.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 3 at 3:38AM EDT until April 4 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow and sleet expected. Total snow accumulations between 7 and 18 inches and sleet accumulations up to around one third of an inch. Localized amounts up to around 24 inches are possible, especially across higher terrain. Winds gusting as high as 55 mph.
* WHERE...Portions of south central, southwest, west central, and western Maine and central and northern New Hampshire.
* WHEN...From 2 PM this afternoon to 8 PM EDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Moderate snow with periods of heavy snow with potential for a foot plus of accumulation will create hazardous travel conditions across the region. Strong gusty winds are expected with the snowstorm, which could cause damage to trees and power lines. Travel is not recommended as heavy snowfall and very low visibility will create extremely dangerous driving conditions. The hazardous conditions will impact the evening and Thursday morning commutes.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...This is a expected to be a long-duration, multi-faceted event. While precipitation starts today, intensity will increase tonight into Thursday when some of the heaviest rates may fall accompanied by strong, gusty winds. Be prepared for a prolonged duration of impact.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Watch issued April 3 at 3:37AM EDT until April 4 at 10:00AM EDT by NWS Boston/Norton MA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...One to two feet of inundation above ground level possible in low-lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways (4.5 to 13.4 feet Mean Lower Low Water).
* WHERE...Eastern Essex, Suffolk, Eastern Norfolk, Eastern Plymouth, Barnstable, Dukes and Nantucket Counties.
* WHEN...Thursday morning.
* IMPACTS...Shallow pockets of flooding less than one foot deep affects the lowest lying areas along the coast, including Morrissey Boulevard in Boston. Most roads remain passable. Flooding up to one foot deep affects coastal roads on the North Shore from Salem to Gloucester and Newburyport. Rough surf will cause flooding on some coastal roads around the time of high tide due to splashover. Roads remain passable. Low lying areas and roads near Nantucket Harbor, including Easy Street, may experience pockets of shallow flooding less than one foot deep. Some roads become impassable. Flooding 1 to 2 feet deep affects low lying areas around Edgartown Harbor, Vineyard Haven, and Oak Bluffs. This includes the Chappy Ferry Dock in Edgartown, Five Corners and Beach Road in Vineyard Haven, and East Chop Drive in Oak Bluffs. Splashover from waves affects Sea View Avenue in Oak Bluffs.

entry.title: Flood Watch issued April 3 at 3:37AM EDT until April 4 at 6:00PM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...Portions of northern Delaware, including the following area, New Castle, New Jersey, including the following areas, Camden, Gloucester, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Morris, Northwestern Burlington, Salem, Somerset, Sussex, Warren and Western Monmouth, and Pennsylvania, including the following areas, Berks, Carbon, Delaware, Eastern Chester, Eastern Montgomery, Lehigh, Lower Bucks, Monroe, Northampton, Philadelphia, Upper Bucks, Western Chester and Western Montgomery.
* WHEN...Through Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Creeks and streams may rise out of their banks. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - Additional rainfall amounts between 1.0 to 3.0 inches are expected across the Watch area into Thursday. About two dozen of our river points are forecast to approach flood stage today into Thursday, with several exceeding flood stage. The rain will be heavy at times, with hourly rates reaching or exceeding an inch, with the more widespread and heaviest rain expected to fall this afternoon and early this evening. During the higher rainfall rates, local flash flooding cannot be ruled out. Excessive runoff may continue to cause rivers, creeks, and streams to rise through the end of the week even when the rain has ended. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued April 3 at 1:14AM MDT until April 5 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT LATE MORNING THROUGH MID EVENING FRIDAY FOR THE NORTHWEST PLATEAU, RIO GRANDE VALLEY, SANDIA AND MANZANO MOUNTAINS BELOW SNOWPACK AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY AND AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE...
.Widespread critical fire weather conditions appear likely on Friday as winds increase ahead of an approaching storm system. These strong winds combined with low humidity will allow for rapid fire spread in dry and receptive fuels. Strong south to southwest winds will peak during the afternoon hours, but will remain elevated through the evening and overnight Friday night.
The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a Fire Weather Watch...which is in effect from Friday morning through Friday evening.
* AREA AND TIMING...This includes the Northwest Plateau (Zone 101), Upper Rio Grande Valley and Lower Chama River Valley (Zone 121), Middle Rio Grande Valley (Zone 106), Sandia and Manzano Mountains below snowpack (Zone 124) and all of eastern New Mexico (Zones 104, 123, 125, and 126) from late Friday morning through Friday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...South to southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts between 40 and 50 mph. The strongest winds are expected across central and western New Mexico, with lighter winds across the eastern plains.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 8 and 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northwest Plateau; Northeast Plains; Middle Rio Grande Valley; Upper Rio Grande Valley and Lower Chama River Valley; Northeast Highlands; Sandia and Manzano Mountains; Central Highlands; East Central Plains

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT FROM FRIDAY MORNING THROUGH FRIDAY EVENING

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 4:41PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A strong storm moving north across the Bering Sea tonight and Wednesday will bring water levels up 2 to 4 feet along the coast from the Bering Strait south on Wednesday and continuer into Thursday. This will cause water to move on top of the ice near the coast in some areas. This could cause trails that cross ice near the coast to become inundated. Ice could push onto the beach along south facing coast lines. This event will be similar what happened March 20, 2024.
Winter Storm Warnings, Watches and Advisories have been issued for most of these areas and are available on the Internet at weather.gov/afg.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast; St Lawrence Island

cap:parameter.value: Strong Storm Causing Water To Move Onto Near Shore Ice Wednesday

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 2 at 2:37PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* A strong cold front will move through the Sierra and western NV late Wednesday through Thursday and bring gusty winds, much colder temperatures, and chances for snow showers.
* Gusty southwest winds will develop Wednesday afternoon north of US-50 and shift to the Eastern Sierra of Mono and Mineral counties overnight into Thursday morning. This will impact outdoor activities, produce bumpy airplane rides, and cause gusty cross winds for high-profile vehicles, especially along US-395, US-95, and I-580. Wind gusts along the Sierra crest will exceed 80 mph.
* Snow showers will increase in northeast CA and the Sierra Wednesday and spread across the region Wednesday night through Friday. Roads will be slick in the Sierra, especially at night. The higher April sun angle will limit accumulations during the daytime hours. Prepare for possible delays if your plans include travel across the Sierra. Total snow accumulations: Above 7000 feet in Greater Lake Tahoe: greater than 6 inches on the west side of Lake Tahoe and 1-2 inches in the Carson Range. Above 7000 feet in Mono County: 3-8 inches. Below 7000 feet in Mono County: trace-4 inches. Lowest Nevada valleys: light snow showers, but no accumulation.
* Unusually cold air will settle into the area for early April with daytime temperatures 15-20 degrees below normal Thursday and Friday and only warming slightly over the weekend. Hard freezes are almost a certainty each night, even for lower western NV valleys beginning Thursday night. Be ready to protect sensitive plants and wrap exposed irrigation systems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Surprise Valley California; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area; Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake; Northern Washoe County

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued April 2 at 3:23PM EDT until April 3 at 7:00PM EDT by NWS Upton NY
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, around 1 ft of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline. For the Coastal Flood Warning, around 2 ft of inundation above ground level expected in vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline.
* WHERE...Southern Queens County.
* WHEN...For the Coastal Flood Advisory, from 2 PM to 7 PM EDT Wednesday. For the Coastal Flood Warning, from 3 AM to 7 AM EDT Thursday.
* COASTAL FLOOD IMPACTS...Widespread minor to moderate flooding of vulnerable areas near the waterfront and shoreline Wed night. Expect around 2 ft of inundation above ground level in low lying, vulnerable areas. This will result in numerous road closures and cause widespread flooding of low lying property including parking lots, parks, lawns and homes/businesses with basements near the waterfront. Vehicles parked in vulnerable areas near the waterfront will likely become flooded. Flooding will also extend inland from the waterfront along tidal rivers and bays.
* SHORELINE IMPACTS...Breaking waves of 4 to 8 ft Wednesday into Thursday morning, along with elevated water levels, will result in beach flooding and erosion. Scattered areas of dune erosion are possible during the times of high tide Wed afternoon into Thursday morning.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...The combination of heavy rain and elevated water levels on Wednesday afternoon into evening may cause localized flash flooding along some shoreline roads and properties. The coverage and magnitude of flooding late Wednesday Night will be dependent on track of low pressure, and timing of windshift from easterly gales to northwest gales. This will be refined over the next 24 hours.

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued April 2 at 1:37PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
AVAGYX
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center, Gorham NH.
The US Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center has issued a backcountry avalanche watch. This avalanche watch does not apply to operating ski areas.
* WHAT...A significant winter storm, bringing the possibility of 30+ inches of snow and strong wind to the higher summits in the Presidential Range, will create dangerous avalanche conditions.
* WHERE...The Presidential Range avalanche forecast area, including but not limited to Tuckerman Ravine, Huntington Ravine, Gulf of Slides, Great Gulf, King Ravine, Burt Ravine, Ammonoosuc Ravine, Oakes Gulf and steep, open terrain in the mountains that are bounded by US Rt 2, US Rt 302, and NH Rt 16. This includes hiking trails that traverse across steep terrain like Summer Lion Head trail. Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside of the coverage area where steep, open terrain exists that has collected drifted snow.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 16:00 EDT to Fri 16:00 EDT.
* IMPACTS... Large, destructive avalanches are likely to occur naturally and spontaneously and will exist throughout steep terrain including hiking trails. These avalanches may be large enough to bury multiple people, do significant damage to trees or buildings, and will likely run far down in paths or areas that are normally safe zones. Precipitation rates are forecast to be heavy, with 1-2 inches of snow falling per hour at times and visibility limited.
